posts.text: The way the first paper goes about sampling from the power distribution is expensive. The second paper figures out a way to sample from an approximation of the same distribution that requires less MCMC exploration (i.e. generates samples faster)

reply_context.text:
The 1st paper shows that sampling with temp isn't actually sampling from the power dist and demonstrates a way to achieve that. Because this is functionally a kind of "look-ahead", it has the effect that it produces results similar to RL training for reasoning, but w/o any addl training.

...

reply_context.text:
The stochasticity of (autoregressive) LLM sampling is usually governed by a "temperature" parameter that takes the functional form of an exponent, so it looks similar to that power distribution.

if X is a monte carlo transition matrix, then taking X to the kth power -- X^k -- gives you the probabilities of transitioning to those states in k-steps.

X^k is the "power" distribution they're describing here.

posts.text:
The biggest risk in this moment is something sociologists call ‚Äúsymbolic compliance.‚Äù

That‚Äôs when an institution that is violating civil rights gives the public just enough symbolic victories that accountability efforts lose steam before there has been any meaningful change.

reply_context.text:
How to speed read AI research:

1. read the second half of the abstract, 
2. Lookover fig 2 and read its caption. 
3. If anything confuses you wrt the fig: find the relevant details in the paper. 
4. After you grok the figure, you'll know if you're still curious enough to dig into methods/results.

posts.text:
How to speed read AI research:

1. read the second half of the abstract, 
2. Lookover fig 2 and read its caption. 
3. If anything confuses you wrt the fig: find the relevant details in the paper. 
4. After you grok the figure, you'll know if you're still curious enough to dig into methods/results.

reply_context.text: I feel very conflicted about this advice: Can you skip parts of papers? Yes! Reading intro+disc first, and methods only optionally, is completely wrong though. IMHO, intro+disc are often lazy world building. Instead, read the methods first to decide whether the rest is even worth looking at.

I think it is about as accurate to describe training a model as a form of "torture" as it is to describe to anti-polarized magnets as "wanting" to be near each other. I think both framings are an abuse of our human notion of subjective experience, and also carry a (tiny) grain of truth.

reply_context.text: and the convergence of the weights characterizes the model settling into its stable "homeostatic" orbit relative to the environment characterized by the loss landscape.
